Tomorrow our district returns to school in a Hybrid/Blended Learning model. Students A-L will attend; Students M-Z will report on Wednesday.

Hybrid/Blended students not attending in-person will be remote learning on the days they are not at school. Please DO NOT send your child to school on a day are not scheduled to be present in-person. Students will be sent home if they come to school when they are not scheduled for in-person attendance.

Remember to certify your child is healthy to attend school before sending them to the bus or to school. Complete the COVID-19 Health Checklist (https://www.kahoks.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/revised-8-19-20-covid-19-daily-student-certification-checklist2020-2021.pdf) every day. If you child does not meet the criteria to attend school, please follow the instructions listed. DO NOT send your child to school.

If you have questions, please contact your child's school.

Collinsville Community Unit School District No. 10 is happy to share that we are updating our district practice for annual student residence verification for compliance with District Policy and Illinois School Code.

In an effort to honor parent and staff time, Collinsville CUSD 10 will be working with a third-party vendor who uses a system called CLEAR Batch to automatically verify parent/guardian residency within the Collinsville CUSD 10 boundaries.

The CLEAR Batch system reviews public records to verify the parent/guardian name and address. In the past, all households were required to verify residency at the initial time of student enrollment for continued enrollment in the District.

This new process will allow Collinsville School District to annually verify parent/guardian residence within the boundaries of the Collinsville CUSD 10.

For details in English: https://www.kahoks.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/annual-erv-announcement-english.pdf

Two CUSD 10 schools are participating in the One School, One Book literacy project. Twin Echo Elementary School will be reading two books as a community.

Today is Census Day! April 1, 2020 - Census Day - is observed nationwide. When you respond to the census, you'll tell the U.S. Census Bureau where you live as of this date.

Every home has an invitation to participate in the 2020 Census. You can respond for your home in one of three ways: online, by phone or by mail. Responses are CONFIDENTIAL and everyone in your household should be counted.

Census data is important to schools because it helps determine the amount of federal funding distributed to states for programs that impact schools, students and families; like special education, after-school programs and classroom technology.

While your family is staying at home during the COVID-10 pandemic, please take a few minutes to respond to the Census and help our schools get the support we deserve. #census2020 #everykidcounts #thekahokway

Collinsville High School Senior Payten Geppert has been honored for her exemplary volunteer service with a 2020 President's Volunteer Service Award.

Last weekend, 28 members of the CHS Math Team competed at the Illinois Council of Teachers of Mathematics, ICTM Regional Contest at SIUE.

Forty-two Dorris Intermediate School students are participating in the "Blast Off with STEM" Space Challenge and were able to view and explore samples from NASA's "Astromaterials Research & Exploration Science Lunar and Meteorite Sample Disc Program" last week.

Students were able to interact with a Lunar and Meteorite Sample Disk that encapsulates six authentic Astromaterials samples in a six-inch diameter clear Lucite disk.

The Meteorite Sample Disk contains six different types of Meteorite samples. And each Lunar Sample Disk contains three Lunar rock and three Lunar soil (regolith) samples collected by Apollo Astronauts.

In addition, students also compared several types of terrestrial rock and mineral samples and were able to explore how the craters on the Moon came to be formed. #thekahokway

The annual Dorris Intermediate School Fifth Grade Festival of Wreaths will conclude with an online auction on Tuesday, December 17, 2019.

"We feel that the gift of giving back to others is an important lesson to share with all our students," said Mrs.Giacoletto.

Fourth graders at Unit 10 Webster Elementary taught everyone the history of the Thanksgiving holiday this morning during their Thanksgiving Play.

Did you know a woman named Sarah Hale is responsible for convincing President Abraham Lincoln to make Thanksgiving a national holiday?

Hale is known as the "Mother of Thanksgiving." After more than three decades of tirelessly trying to win recognition for a national day of thanks, she finally convinced Lincoln to sign a proclamation in 1863 naming the fourth Thursday in November as "Thanksgiving Day."

The students shared the story of how the Pilgrims' first Thanksgiving inspired Hale to convince President Lincoln to declare the holiday to help heal the nation divided by the Civil War.

They reminded everyone to remember the meaning behind the holiday as they gather with family and friends this year. CUSD 10 schools are closed Wednesday, Thursday and Friday this week in observance of Thanksgiving. #thekahokway #proudtobeakahok
